bibl.title: Letter from H. McG. Robertson to [Hugh S. Cumming], January 3, 1923

div1.p: Robertson inquires about the possibility of doing a flea survey and discusses threat of a plague.

div1.head: Letter from H. McG. Robertson to [Hugh S. Cumming], January 3, 1923
div1.opener:
Further relative to necessity
for flea survey.
H. McG. Robertson, Surgeon.
1110 Capitol Street,
Richmond, Virginia,
January 3, 1923.
The Surgeon General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D.C.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to invite the attention of the Bureau
to my letter of May 9 last relative to making a flea survey of
the cities of our Atlantic Coast, and requesting that I be assign-
ed to that duty. In regard to this request I may say that I am
very much interested in my present work and prefer to be con-
tinued on duty with the Virginia State Board of Health, yet I
cannot get rid of the idea that this flea survey should be made,
- possibly not in so many places as suggested in my letter, yet
at least in some City far enough north, say Washington or
Baltimore, to give a definite idea of the seasonal prevalence of
fleas at that point. The prevalence further north would of course
be less.

My attention was drawn to this subject at this time by
the attached clipping from a late copy of the Journal of the
American Medical Association. From the point of view of one whose
beliefs, are as expressed in my letter of May 9, 1922, it is as
useless to search for plague infected rats in our North Atlantic
Cities between December 15 and April 1 as it would be to search
for yellow fever cases in the human population of New Orleans at
the same time. Certainly until a flea survey is made any anti-
plague work that is done is based on a knowledge that is in-
complete insofar as one of the factors in the spread of Plague
is concerned. In a general way it is known to all of us that
fleas are scarce in the winter months, but to leave the matter
at this point is unscientific and unnecessary.

In speaking to different persons of the advisability to
making this flea survey I have been met with a good many sugges-
tions as to the uselessness of the work. It has been said that
the great plague of London continued through the cold months.
It may be said that yellow fever in years past existed in
Philadelphia, yet various causes have conspired to rid Philadel-
phia of this disease and make it impossible for it to get an
extensive foothold in that City.

It has been said that plague occurs the year around in
Manchuria, yet, if I am correctly informed, this is the pneumonic
form of plague.

Someone advanced the idea that it would be necessary
to search the nests of rats for fleas. It seems that it is
immaterial where the fleas may be in the winter months if they
are not on the rats.

It has also been said that some cases of plague would
continue as chronic cases into the winter and spring. If this
is so they would be entirely harmless during the winter, but
would probably die or recover before the flea season began in
the spring.

It is not alone our North Atlantic Seaboard that is
free from plague - Canadian ports both eastern and western have
never been plague infected, nor have any of the Scandanavian
ports, to the best of my knowledge, though no quarantine efforts
have been made in any of the countries mentioned to exclude this
disease. In Great Britain during the past 25 years there have
occurred about fourteen outbreaks of plague, only one of which
lasted for more than a week or two. This was an epidemic in
Glasgow in the fall of 1900 in which 28 cases occurred with 4
deaths. If Great Britain during these years, without any
quarantine protection and in intimate daily shipping contact
with India and other plague centres has suffered so little
from this disease, it seems that the fumigation of the large
passenger liners plying only between North European ports and
the ports of our North Atlantic Coast might be omitted except
as some particular occasion might arise. It is my idea that
the quarantine procedure in case of bubonic plague might be
modified along the line now in practice in case of yellow fever,
if my theory of a seasonal distribution of fleas is correct.

If plague should break out in the late summer or fall
in any of our cities north, say, of Savannah, an intensive cam-
paign in the immediate vicinity of the outbreak would be sufficient
and the inaugurating of city-wide rat-proofing with its attendant
financial and legal difficulties would be avoided.

I am mentioning more in detail than in my former letter
these two instances of the possible practical effects that might
follow changed ideas based on an accurate knowledge of the flea
prevalence in any given locality because it has been suggested
that definite knowledge along this line would be of academic
value only.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, (Signed) H. McG. Robertson
Surgeon. HMR/MBD
